blogPosts.title: 5 Essential React Tips for Better Code
blogPosts.author: Mohan Ram
blogPosts.description: Quick tips to improve your React development workflow and code quality with practical examples.
blogPosts.summary: Master these five essential React patterns to write cleaner, more maintainable code. From custom hooks to component composition, learn how to leverage React's powerful features effectively.

authorBio.name: Mohan Ram
authorBio.title: Full Stack Developer & ML Specialist
authorBio.bio: With 7+ years of experience in software development, I specialize in building scalable web applications and ML solutions. Passionate about clean code and developer experience.

content.text: React has revolutionized how we build user interfaces, but with great power comes the need for great practices. After years of working with React, I've compiled five essential tips that will elevate your code quality and development experience.
1. Use Custom Hooks for Reusable Logic
Custom hooks are one of React's most powerful features. They allow you to extract component logic into reusable functions, making your code **cleaner** and more **maintainable**.
This custom hook handles all localStorage logic in one place. You can now use it across your entire application with a simple function call.
2. Optimize with useMemo and useCallback
Performance optimization is crucial for smooth user experiences. Use `useMemo` for expensive calculations and `useCallback` for function references that are passed to child components.

content.caption: Optimize your React app with memoization techniques

items: **useMemo**: Memoize computed values to avoid recalculation
**useCallback**: Prevent unnecessary re-renders of child components
**React.memo**: Wrap components that receive the same props frequently

content.text: 3. Component Composition Over Props Drilling
Instead of passing props through multiple levels, use *composition patterns* and the Context API. This makes your component tree more flexible and easier to maintain.
4. Error Boundaries Are Essential
Don't let a single component crash your entire app. Implement error boundaries to catch JavaScript errors anywhere in the component tree and display fallback UI.

content.caption: Graceful error handling improves user experience

content.text: 5. Keep Your Components Small and Focused
The Single Responsibility Principle applies to React components too. If a component does too much, break it down. __Smaller components__ are easier to test, debug, and reuse.
A component should do one thing and do it well. If it's doing more, it's time to refactor.
content.author: Clean Code Principles

content.text: These five tips have dramatically improved my React development workflow. Start implementing them today and watch your code quality soar! ðŸš€

blogPosts.title: Deploying to AWS: A Complete Guide
blogPosts.author: Mohan Ram
blogPosts.description: Step-by-step guide to deploying your web application on AWS infrastructure with best practices.
blogPosts.summary: Learn how to deploy production-ready applications on AWS with EC2, S3, CloudFront, and automated CI/CD pipelines. This comprehensive guide covers everything from setup to monitoring.

authorBio.name: Mohan Ram
authorBio.title: Full Stack Developer & ML Specialist
authorBio.bio: With 7+ years of experience in software development, I specialize in building scalable web applications and ML solutions. Passionate about clean code and developer experience.

content.text: Amazon Web Services (AWS) has become the de facto standard for cloud deployment. This comprehensive guide will walk you through deploying a production-ready web application on AWS.
Prerequisites
Step 1: Set Up EC2 Instance

EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud) provides scalable computing capacity. Choose an instance type based on your application's needsâ€”*t2.micro* is perfect for small applications and falls under the free tier.

content.caption: AWS provides scalable cloud infrastructure for any application size

content.text:
# Connect to your EC2 instance
ssh -i "your-key.pem" ec2-user@your-instance-ip

# Update system packages
sudo yum update -y

# Install Node.js (for Node apps)
curl -sL https://rpm.nodesource.com/setup_18.x | sudo bash -
sudo yum install -y nodejs

# Install nginx
sudo yum install -y nginx
sudo systemctl start nginx
sudo systemctl enable nginx
Step 2: Configure Security Groups
Security is __critical__. Set up security groups to control inbound and outbound traffic. At minimum, allow HTTP (80), HTTPS (443), and SSH (22) access.
Step 3: Deploy with S3 and CloudFront
For static sites, combine S3 for storage and CloudFront for content delivery. This setup is highly scalable, cost-effective, and provides excellent performance worldwide.

# Install AWS CLI
curl "https://awscli.amazonaws.com/awscli-exe-linux-x86_64.zip" -o "awscliv2.zip"
unzip awscliv2.zip
sudo ./aws/install

# Configure AWS credentials
aws configure

# Create S3 bucket
aws s3 mb s3://your-bucket-name

# Upload to S3
aws s3 sync ./build s3://your-bucket-name

# Invalidate CloudFront cache
aws cloudfront create-invalidation \
  --distribution-id YOUR_DIST_ID \
  --paths "/*"

content.caption: CloudFront delivers your content from edge locations worldwide

content.text: Setting Up CI/CD with GitHub Actions
Automate your deployment process with GitHub Actions. Here's a complete workflow file:

name: Deploy to AWS

on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v2
    
    - name: Configure AWS credentials
      uses: aws-actions/configure-aws-credentials@v1
      with:
        aws-access-key-id: ${{ secrets.AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID }}
        aws-secret-access-key: ${{ secrets.AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY }}
        aws-region: us-east-1
    
    - name: Build application
      run: |
        npm install
        npm run build
    
    - name: Deploy to S3
      run: aws s3 sync ./build s3://your-bucket-name
    
    - name: Invalidate CloudFront
      run: |
        aws cloudfront create-invalidation \
          --distribution-id ${{ secrets.CLOUDFRONT_ID }} \
          --paths "/*"
The cloud is about how you do computing, not where you do computing.
content.author: Paul Maritz, VMware CEO

content.text: With this setup, you're ready to serve millions of users with confidence. Remember to monitor your costs and optimize as you scale! â˜ï¸
